questions.text: Which of the following mood stabilizers causes hepatitis ? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Valproate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ Valproate, a commonly used mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder, is associated hepatitis. Regular monitoring of liver function tests is crucial in patients on valproate therapy to detect and manage potential liver damage early.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl arrives with several swellings and numerous brown rashes. Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas. There are irregularities in her biochemical values. Additionally, she has a past medical record of hypothyroidism. The provided image displays an X-ray of her femur. What is the probable diagnosis from the options provided?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. McCune-Albright syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presentation of several swellings and numerous brown rashes represents café Au lait spots . Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas. There are irregularities in her biochemical values. Presence of past medical history of hypothyroidism, and Shepherd crook deformity of femur in the given image, all point towards the McCune Albright Syndrome .
  • ➤ The presentation of several swellings and numerous brown rashes represents café Au lait spots .
  • ➤ café Au lait spots
  • ➤ Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas.
  • ➤ There are irregularities in her biochemical values.
  • ➤ Presence of past medical history of hypothyroidism, and Shepherd crook deformity of femur in the given image, all point towards the McCune Albright Syndrome .
  • ➤ McCune Albright Syndrome

questions.text: Organize the listed bands within the sarcomere, starting from the periphery and moving towards the center. (INICET MAY 2023) Z line M line A band H zone
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1,3,4,2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct order of bands within the sarcomere, from the periphery towards the center, is Z line, A band, H zone, and M line.

questions.text: A patient presents with fatigue, pallor, and weakness. On evaluation, CBC reveals low hemoglobin and reduced reticulocyte count. His WBC and platelet count were normal. BM examination reveals selective reduction in the erythroid precursors. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient's presentation is classic for red cell aplasia. Think about what's happening here - the patient has anemia (shown by fatigue, pallor, weakness, and low hemoglobin), but interestingly, only the red blood cell line is affected. The white cells and platelets are completely normal.
  • • The hallmark of red cell aplasia is that there is a selective reduction in erythroid precursors. The reduced reticulocyte count is also important as it tell us that the bone marrow isn't even trying to compensate for the anemia
  • • Red cell aplasia can happen for several reasons - parvovirus B19 infection, certain medications, autoimmune disorders, or sometimes associated with thymomas.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A : Aplastic anaemia If this were aplastic anemia, our patient would be having pancytopenia (low counts across all cell types). Our patient's normal WBC and platelets immediately rule this out. Option C : Iron deficiency anemia; in IDA, the body typically responds by pumping out more reticulocytes to try to compensate. Our patient has reduced Reticulocyte count ruling this out. Option D : Hemolytic anemia would show increased red cell precursors leading to high reticulocyte count.
  • • Option A : Aplastic anaemia If this were aplastic anemia, our patient would be having pancytopenia (low counts across all cell types). Our patient's normal WBC and platelets immediately rule this out.
  • • Option A
  • • Option C : Iron deficiency anemia; in IDA, the body typically responds by pumping out more reticulocytes to try to compensate. Our patient has reduced Reticulocyte count ruling this out.
  • • Option C
  • • Option D : Hemolytic anemia would show increased red cell precursors leading to high reticulocyte count.
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This question tests knowledge of the differential diagnosis of anemia based on bone marrow findings and cellular indices. Specifically, it assesses the ability to recognize the characteristic pattern of red cell aplasia: selective reduction of erythroid precursors with normal myeloid and megakaryocytic lines, accompanied by anemia and low reticulocyte count. The key distinguishing feature is the selective involvement of only the red cell line, differentiating it from other anemias that show different patterns of cell production or destruction.

questions.text: Which of the following in IgA vasculitis warrants the use of corticosteroids? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Corticosteroids are indicated in IgA vasculitis primarily for severe manifestations such as gastrointestinal bleeding, indicating more extensive disease involvement. Other manifestations, such as arthritis, abdominal pain, and skin rash, are generally self-limiting and respond well to supportive care. Corticosteroids are not typically required for these symptoms unless they are part of a more severe systemic involvement.

questions.text: Antepartum hemorrhage due to abruption shows all except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Painless vaginal bleeding

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Painless vaginal bleeding is not a feature of abruption of the placenta. It is a characteristic feature of placenta previa. Patients with placental abruption present with sudden-onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions. Abruptio placenta is the partial or total separation of a normally implanted placenta before delivery, leading to bleeding and other complications.
  • • Painless vaginal bleeding is not a feature of abruption of the placenta. It is a characteristic feature of placenta previa.
  • • Painless vaginal bleeding
  • • Patients with placental abruption present with sudden-onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions.
  • • Abruptio placenta is the partial or total separation of a normally implanted placenta before delivery, leading to bleeding and other complications.
  • • Abruptio placenta
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Uterine tenderness : This is a common feature of placental abruption due to the separation of the placenta from the uterine wall.
  • • Option A. Uterine tenderness
  • • Option B. Frequent contractions : Increased frequency of uterine contractions is associated with placental abruption.
  • • Option B. Frequent contractions
  • • Option D. Mild to moderate vaginal bleeding : Vaginal bleeding of varying degrees, from mild to severe, is typically seen in placental abruption.
  • • Option D. Mild to moderate vaginal bleeding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Placental abruption presents with sudden-onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions, but not with painless vaginal bleeding, which is characteristic of placenta previa.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg1944, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 297
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26 th edition pg1944, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg 297

questions.text: Which are the tumor markers for the ultrasound image shown below? (NEET PG 2024) CA 125 LDH AFP hCG CA 19-9
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1,2,3,4,5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Different tumor markers, including CA 125, LDH, AFP, hCG, and CA 19-9, are utilized to assess ovarian masses and differentiate between various types of ovarian tumors.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child complains of mild painful swelling over the scalp for 3 months as shown in the image below. He also has a pet dog at his home. What is the diagnosis of the given condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Kerion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kerion is a boggy, tender scalp swelling associated with hair loss and potentially linked to animal exposure, indicative of a f ungal infection rather than a bacterial cause like furuncle or folliculitis, or a benign lesion such as an epidermoid cyst.
  • ➤ Kerion
  • ➤ boggy,
  • ➤ scalp swelling
  • ➤ hair loss
  • ➤ ungal

References:

  • ↳ Reference:
  • ↳ Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 26.22, 26.23-26.24, 32.38, 32.39, 32.40, 90.27, 108.11
  • ↳ Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 26.22, 26.23-26.24, 32.38, 32.39, 32.40, 90.27, 108.11

questions.text: Which protein is present in the HPV vaccine? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) L1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The HPV vaccine contains the L1 protein, which forms virus-like particles that induce an immune response to prevent infection by various HPV types, significantly reducing the risk of HPV-associated cancers and genital warts.

questions.text: Multiple Lisch nodules are a feature of which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neurofibromatosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lisch nodules are pigmented iris hamartomas specific to Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) and are an important diagnostic feature of this condition.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertical diplopia while walking downstairs. To correct that, he tilts the head on one shoulder. Which nerve palsy is suspected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 4th CN palsy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presenting with vertical diplopia while walking downstairs and tilting the head on one shoulder to correct the vision suggests a 4th cranial nerve (CN) palsy. The 4th cranial nerve, also known as the trochlear nerve, innervates the superior oblique muscle.
  • • superior oblique muscle.
  • • The primary actions of the superior oblique muscle include intorsion, depression, and abduction of the eye.
  • • intorsion,
  • • When there is a palsy of the 4th cranial nerve, the affected eye may have difficulty performing these movements, leading to vertical diplopia. Patients often adopt a compensatory head tilt to align the eyes properly and alleviate the double vision. The head tilt is typically towards the shoulder opposite the affected eye, compensating for the muscle's inability to properly intort and depress the eye.
  • • compensatory head tilt to align the eyes
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 3rd CN palsy : This palsy typically presents with ptosis (drooping eyelid) and an eye that is deviated down and out. Patients often lift their chin to see beneath the drooping lid, not to correct vertical diplopia.
  • • Option A. 3rd CN palsy
  • • Option C. 6th CN palsy : The 6th cranial nerve innervates the lateral rectus muscle, responsible for abduction of the eye. A palsy here would result in horizontal diplopia, not vertical diplopia, and the patient might turn their head to compensate, not tilt it.
  • • Option C. 6th CN palsy
  • • Option D. 7th CN palsy : This nerve controls facial muscles, and its palsy leads to facial muscle weakness or paralysis, not issues related to eye movement or diplopia.
  • • Option D. 7th CN palsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 4th cranial nerve palsy (trochlear nerve palsy) leads to vertical diplopia, which patients often compensate for by tilting their head to the opposite shoulder to align the eyes and improve vision.
  • ➤ Mnemonic – SO4 LR6 and rest all by cranial nerve 3
  • ➤ Mnemonic – SO4 LR6 and rest all by cranial nerve 3
  • ➤ Superior oblique by 4 th CN; Lateral rectus by 6 th CN and Rest all muscle by 3 rd CN
  • ➤ Superior oblique by 4 th CN; Lateral rectus by 6 th CN and Rest all muscle by 3 rd CN

questions.text: Prolonged bleeding time is seen in? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Von Willebrand disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prolonged bleeding time and prolonged APTT is seen in Von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with an unconscious state. An arterial blood analysis reveals the following values: pH = 7.1; PCO2 = 22 mmHg; HCO3- = 16 mEq/l. Identify the patient’s condition. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Metabolic acidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of metabolic acidosis, both the pH and bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels are decreased, and the respiratory system may compensate by lowering PCO2.

questions.text: A 20-year-old sexual assault victim was examined in court "in camera." What does it imply? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Closed proceeding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ "In camera" refers to a closed proceeding in court where only selected individuals are allowed to be present, ensuring the privacy of sensitive cases such as those involving sexual assault.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a known history of thalassemia undergoes blood transfusion. Following the transfusion, she developed symptoms of anxiety, hypotension, and fever. What is the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Stop the blood transfusion and push normal saline

options.label: B
options.text: Continue the blood transfusion and perform an ECG

options.label: C
options.text: Investigate for clerical errors in the blood transfusion process

options.label: D
options.text: Administer corticosteroids and monitor vital signs

questions.correct_answer: A. Stop the blood transfusion and push normal saline
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stop the blood transfusion and push normal saline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the event of suspected transfusion reactions, characterized by symptoms like anxiety, hypotension, and fever, the immediate action should be to stop the blood transfusion and push normal saline to prevent further complications.

questions.text: Identify the finding in the given ultrasound image. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Phrygian cap

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Phrygian cap is the most common congenital anatomic variant of the gallbladder, appearing as a fold at the gallbladder fundus. It is asymptomatic and has no pathological significance, important to recognize in imaging to differentiate it from potential abnormalities.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy came with a tumor resembling a mushroom in the distal femur, which has been present for the last two years. What characteristics should the clinician look for to discern a potential malignant transformation? (INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint.

options.label: B
options.text: Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential.

options.label: C
options.text: Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone.

options.label: D
options.text: Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

questions.correct_answer: D. Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The malignant transformation of osteochondroma is suspected when the hyaline cap thickness is 2cm, as seen on the MRI.

questions.text: A posthumous child can be best defined as: (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: B
options.text: Child is delivered after death of biological father

options.label: C
options.text: Child is born to an unmarried couple

options.label: D
options.text: Child is abandoned by the parents

questions.correct_answer: B. Child is delivered after death of biological father
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Child is delivered after death of biological father

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A posthumous child is one who is born after the death of one of their biological parents, most commonly the father.

questions.text: A couple presents to the OPD with their 4-year-old child who has self-mutilating behavior and poor growth. Identify the condition and enzyme involved in it: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) HGPRT deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome is caused by a complete deficiency of HGPRT, leading to self-mutilation, poor growth, hyperuricemia, and gout.

questions.text: What is the appropriate technique to measure the placement of a nasogastric tube? (INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.

options.label: B
options.text: From the angle of the mouth to the tragus to the xiphisternum.

options.label: C
options.text: From the ala of the nose to the angle of the mandible to the xiphisternum.

options.label: D
options.text: From the angle of the mouth to the ear lobule to the umbilicus

questions.correct_answer: A. From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) From the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To determine the appropriate length of a nasogastric tube (also known as Ryle's tube) used for treating intestinal obstruction or providing nutritional support, the NEX method is commonly used, which involves measuring from the tip of the nose to the ear lobule to the xiphisternum. The approximate length to be inserted is around 55 cm. The preferred position for inserting the Ryle's tube is in a sitting position with the neck slightly flexed.
  • ➤ The proper positioning of the tube can be confirmed through auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air or by an abdominal radiograph. The ideal placement for an NG tube used for suction is within the stomach to avoid damage to the duodenum. In contrast, an NG feeding tube should be placed post-pyloric to reduce the risk of aspiration.
  • ➤ Indications for NG tube usage include gastric decompression in intestinal obstruction, aspiration of gastric fluid, nutritional support, and medication administration. However, some absolute contraindications to NG tube insertion include severe midface trauma and recent nasal surgery.
  • ➤ A tray of specialized instruments is used for nasogastric tube insertion, including a lubricating jelly, an NG tube, a syringe, and gloves, among others.

questions.text: Image of Rickettsial morula in a monocyte is shown below. Identify the organism? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Ehrlichia chaffeensis

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department with symptoms that have persisted for five days, including high-grade fever, severe headache, generalized body aches, and a new cough accompanied by mild shortness of breath. She also reports noticing a blackish lesion at the site of an insect bite on her thigh after returning from a camping trip in a region known for chigger infestation. On physical examination, she is found to have a fever of 39°C, regional lymphadenopathy, and a well-defined eschar at the site of the lesion. Lung auscultation reveals mild diffuse rales. Laboratory tests show a normal white blood cell count and elevated liver enzymes. A chest X-ray indicates interstitial infiltrates, suggestive of atypical pneumonia that may be related to her primary infection. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intravenous doxycycline only.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for rickettsial infections, such as those contracted from chigger bites, and is effective against both the primary infection and associated complications like atypical pneumonia.
  • ➤ Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for rickettsial infections, such as those contracted from chigger bites, and is effective against both the primary infection and associated complications like atypical pneumonia.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of acute-onset severe abdominal pain. The patient is conscious, alert, and hemodynamically stable. Upon examination, the patient reports that the pain began suddenly. A chest X-ray is performed, which reveals some abnormal findings. Identify the condition shown below and its management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Emergency laparotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hollow viscus perforation is a surgical emergency that presents with acute abdominal pain and may be confirmed by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray. Immediate surgical intervention, typically via emergency laparotomy, is required to address the perforation and prevent peritonitis.
  • ➤ Hollow viscus perforation is a surgical emergency that presents with acute abdominal pain and may be confirmed by the presence of free air under the diaphragm on a chest X-ray.
  • ➤ Immediate surgical intervention, typically via emergency laparotomy, is required to address the perforation and prevent peritonitis.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone is released from zona fasciculata? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glucocorticoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex is responsible for producing glucocorticoids, mainly cortisol.

questions.text: Cushing's ulcers are seen in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Head injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cushing's ulcers are a specific type of peptic ulcer that occurs due to increased intracranial pressure resulting from head injuries. Recognizing this condition is important for managing patients with significant neurological trauma to prevent and treat these potentially serious gastrointestinal complications.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of loose stools with an increase in frequency for 4 days. On examination, he is drowsy, unable to feed, and skin on pinching goes back very slowly. According to the integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness (IMNCI), this child will be classified as having: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Severe dehydration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A child with signs of lethargy, poor feeding, and slow skin pinch return should be classified as having severe dehydration and managed urgently as per IMNCI guidelines.

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: D
options.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.correct_answer: C. CSF PCR for viral DNA
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CSF PCR for viral DNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a rapid and accurate diagnosis of HSV encephalitis, CSF PCR for viral DNA is the gold standard, essential for guiding appropriate antiviral therapy.

questions.text: What is the vector for Orientia tsutsugamushi? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The vector for Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is the mite, specifically the larval stage known as chiggers.

questions.text: Which of the following is a virilizing ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arrhenoblastoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arrhenoblastoma is a virilizing ovarian tumor known for its androgen production, often leading to masculinizing symptoms in females.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Failure of migration of neural crest cells

questions.correct_answer: A. Failure of migration of neural crest cells
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Failure of migration of neural crest cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hirschsprung disease is primarily caused by the failure of neural crest cells to migrate to the bowel wall during embryonic development, resulting in aganglionosis in the distal bowel and leading to functional obstruction and proximal bowel dilation.

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. VIP

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • VIP is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine.
  • • During peristalsis, segment of intestine behind the bolus contracts while segment in front of it relaxes.
  • • Cholinergic neurons in the anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxes the segment of the intestine in front of the bolus.
  • • Cholinergic neurons in the retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which contracts the segment of the intestine behind the bolus.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Acetylcholine : Incorrect as acetylcholine is involved in the contraction of the intestinal segment behind the bolus, not in the dilatation.
  • • Option B. Acetylcholine
  • • Option C. Substance P : Incorrect because it also contributes to the contraction of the intestinal muscles behind the bolus.
  • • Option C. Substance P
  • • Option D. Serotonin : Incorrect as serotonin is involved in overall motility and secretion within the gut but not specifically in anterograde dilatation as described here.
  • • Option D. Serotonin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ VIP is crucial for the anterograde dilatation of the small intestine, promoting the relaxation of the intestinal segment ahead of the bolus during peristalsis, thereby facilitating the forward movement of intestinal contents.

questions.text: Anuj has been diagnosed with diphtheria and is being treated in the ward. His 3-year-old brother, Ajay who lives in the same house has received vaccination against diphtheria about 16 months back. What is the next best step for the management of the younger sibling, Ajay? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: B
options.text: Nothing as the child is already exposed

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Erythromycin only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a close contact of a diphtheria patient who has received the diphtheria vaccination within the last five years, antibiotic prophylaxis with erythromycin is the appropriate management step.

questions.text: An infant is brought by his parents with complaints that his urine turns black on standing. Which of the following metabolic disorders is likely? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Alkaptonuria

questions.text: A fetus with intrauterine growth restriction was born prematurely with jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and diffuse petechiae at birth. A brain CT was done which revealed periventricular calcifications. What is the best method for the diagnosis of the etiological agent? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Urine examination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Urine examination is the preferred diagnostic method for identifying congenital cytomegalovirus infection, which typically presents with symptoms such as intrauterine growth restriction, prematurity, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, microcephaly, diffuse petechiae, and periventricular calcifications.

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which investigation can be detrimental to this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. MRI

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MRI is contraindicated for patients with suspected metallic foreign bodies in the eye due to the risk of movement and further injury caused by the magnetic fields.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Earache

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.
  • ➤ Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 81
  • ➤ Ref - Source Dhingra 7th edition pg 81

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall from height. The patient reports no pain or injury, but on examination, there is blood at the tip of the urethral meatus. The patient is hemodynamically stable with no other injuries. The next step in management would be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ascending urethrogram

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To confirm urethral rupture in a patient with suspected urethral injury, an ascending urethrogram is the next step in management. Foley's catheterization should be avoided as it may exacerbate the injury.
  • ➤ To confirm urethral rupture in a patient with suspected urethral injury, an ascending urethrogram is the next step in management.
  • ➤ Foley's catheterization should be avoided as it may exacerbate the injury.

questions.text: Regarding urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2022) Most common cause of UTI is Streptococcus pneumoniae. Bowel, bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence. Cotrimoxazole is not given. Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is done in children with recurrence of UTI.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that bowel and bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrent UTIs in children, and that MCU is performed in cases of recurrent UTI to assess for anatomical and functional abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding rotavirus vaccine? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: D
options.text: Rotavirus should not be given after 6 months

questions.correct_answer: D. Rotavirus should not be given after 6 months
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The catch-up schedule for the rotavirus vaccine extends up to one year of age, contrary to the incorrect statement that it should not be given after 6 months.

questions.text: A 16-year-old presents with absent menses. Examination shows widely spaced nipples, webbed neck, and Tanner grade 1 breast development. USG shows streak ovaries. Investigation shows raised FSH, raised LH, and reduced estradiol. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Turner syndrome is characterized by primary amenorrhea, streak ovaries, hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, widely spaced nipples, and a webbed neck.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3 rd edition pg411, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg 441
